The 'Society of the Muslim Brothers'  (, often simply: , the 'Muslim
Brotherhood', transliterated: {{transl|ar|DIN|al-Ê¾Iká¸«wÄn al-MuslimÅ«n}}) is
the Arab world's oldest, most influential and one of the largest Islamic
movements, and is the largest political opposition organization in many Arab st-
ates. [http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/2010/11/2010111681527837704.html
The Muslim Brotherhood in flux] 21 November 2010 aljazeera [http://www.ikhwanweb.com/Home.asp?zPage=Systems&System=PressR&Press-
=Show&Lang=E&ID=6674 The Moderate Muslim Brotherhood]. Robert S. Leiken & Steven
Brooke, Foreign Affairs Magazine Founded in Egypt in 1928 Bruce
Rutherford ,Egypt After Mubarak(Princeton: Princeton UP, 2008),99 as a Pan-
Islamic, religious, political, and social movement by the Islamic scholar and
schoolteacher Hassan al-Banna, by the end of
World War II the Muslim Brotherhood had an estimated two million members. Hallett, Robin. Africa Since 1875. Ann Arbor,
Michigan: The University of Michigan Press (1974), p. 138. Its ideas had
gained supporters throughout the Arab world and influenced other Islamist groups
with its "model of political activism combined with Islamic charity work".

 The Brotherhood's stated goal is to instill the Qur'an and
Sunnah as the "sole reference point for ...ordering the life of the Muslim
family, individual, community ... and state." The movement is known for
engaging in political violence, claiming responsibility for the installation of
Hamas. [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A12823-
2004Sep10.html THE WORLD AFTER 9/11 : The Muslim Brotherhood In America]
Muslim Brotherhood members are suspected to have assassinated political
opponents like Egyptian Prime Minister Mahmoud an-Nukrashi Pasha. Lia, Brynjar. The Society of the Muslim Brothers in Egypt: The Rise
of an Islamic Mass Movement 1928-1942. Ithica Press, 2006. p. 53

 The Muslim Brotherhood started as a religious social
organization; preaching Islam, teaching the illiterate, setting up hospitals and
even launching commercial enterprises. As it continued to rise in influence,
starting in 1936, it began to oppose British rule in Egypt. Many Egyptian nationalists accuse the Muslim Brotherhood of
violent killings during this period. Chamieh, Jebran,
Traditionalists, Militants and Liberal in Present Islam, Research and Publishing
House, 1994?, p. 140. After the Arab defeat in the First Arab-Israeli war,
the Egyptian government dissolved the organisation and arrested its members. It supported the Egyptian Revolution of 1952, but after an
attempted assassination of Egypt's president it was once again banned and
repressed. The Muslim Brotherhood has been
suppressed in other countries as well, most notably in Syria in 1982 during the
Hama massacre.

 The Muslim Brotherhood is financed by contributions from its
members, who are required to allocate a portion of their income to the movement.
Some of these contributions are from members who work in Saudi Arabia and other
oil-rich countries.
categories: Russian Federal Security Service designated terrorist organizations
